awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  P2C2--Multi-Century Perspectives on Current and Future Flow in the Lower Missouri River Basin
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to provide high-quality, long-term records of past streamflow in the Lower Missouri River (LMR) basin by integrating select gage records, modeled hydrology, and several complementary dendrochronology reconstruction approaches focusing on water-year and seasonal generation of runoff and the improved capture of extremes. This project seeks to: (1) incorporate gage data, estimates of natural flow, and modeled hydrology to develop streamflow calibration series; (2) generate reconstructions of streamflow for key sub-basin gages in the LMR, along with spatial reconstructions of runoff for the basin; (3) evaluate multi-century synoptic climate controls on LMR flow within a broader North American context; and (4) analyze the impact of warming temperatures on future flow patterns.

Extreme events (floods and droughts) have been common in the LMR over the past several decades, but the context for understanding the long-term hydroclimate variability impacting flow is limited due to a paucity of long streamflow records that are unaffected by human modification.  The LMR basin is one of the few remaining major river systems in the U.S. lacking streamflow reconstructions in large part due to the scarcity of reliable instrumental data for flow calibration

The potential Broader Impacts (B.I.) include an improved baseline understanding of droughts/floods/pluvials in the Lower Missouri River Basin and the involvement of stakeholders at all levels including water resource managers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Missouri River Basin encompasses nearly one-sixth of the area of the coterminous United States and supplies water to a vast network of users for farming, municipal water, industry, and recreation. In addition, The MRB provides critical aquatic habitat for a large range of fish and wildlife as well. Yet, the Missouri River is one of the more poorly understood river systems with respect to long-term variability and change. The instrumental and modeled streamflow records for the MRB only extend back as far as 1900. This is too short to provide the full range of variability of low flows and floods to be useful for understanding the kinds of variability that might occur in the future. To better understand and model the causes of Lower Missouri River Basin streamflow variability, which includes streamflow from the Upper Missouri River Basin as well, the National Science Foundation funded a collaborative, multi-institutional, research project titled “Multi-Century Perspectives on Current and Future Flow in the Lower Missouri River Basin.”

A critical component of this research is the use of long tree-ring records to reconstruct past Lower Missouri River Basin streamflow back hundreds of years in the past. For this purpose, a network of long tree-ring chronologies in and around the full Missouri River Basin was created. This process included fieldwork to update critical tree-ring sites last sampled in the 1980s and 1990s to enable the Lower Missouri River Basin reconstruction to be made up to 2020. The final tree-ring network created by this project totaled 885 annual tree-ring chronologies, many of which were 600 or more years in length. This tree-ring network was then used to reconstruct total water year (October-September) river discharge at the Hermann, Missouri river gage (HEMO) not far from where the Missouri River empties into the Mississippi River. This reconstruction therefore estimates the discharge of the full Missouri River Basin, a result never before accomplished. It covers the period 1360-2020 and in so doing provides an enormous amount of new information for assessing the long-term variability of Missouri River discharge and determining its causes. A plot showing this reconstruction is provided.

As part of this project, it was important to also understand the drivers of variability in this river system over time. We used both instrumental and model data to disentangle the factors influencing streamflow trends, including land use changes, climate variability, and anthropogenic climate change. We studied how the Great Plains Low-Level Jet (a fast moving ribbon of air in the low levels of the atmosphere that can rapidly transport Gulf moisture and warmer temperatures up into the Missouri River Basin) influences precipitation and streamflow in the central U.S. This was done both over the past several centuries with a reconstruction of the wind and moisture components of the Jet back to 1690 CE, and into the future using climate model projections. We were able to integrate our new Lower Missouri River flow reconstruction at HEMO with a previous reconstruction of the Upper Missouri River to better understand the connections between the different regions of the large Missouri River Basin and how they interact over time and space. Combined results from these research areas show the enormous amount of variability in these systems over multiple centuries. We found that moisture transport into this region is projected to increase in the future, with important implications for precipitation, streamflow, and flooding.

Beyond these scientific contributions, this project has broader implications for science and society. The methods developed through this project will be more widely applicable to other studies that are hindered by sparse or inadequate data, a common issue in paleoclimate studies. Through this project, we have increased understanding of the drivers of high-flow events that can lead to flooding in the Missouri River Basin, and how these drivers might change in the future. This also includes improved estimates of flood frequency and placing the great Missouri River flood of 1993 in a long-term context. This project involved direct engagement with resource managers through meetings and workshops, with the aim of producing past reconstructions and future projections that can be used as input into operational river system models. Our research is relevant to resource professionals currently dealing with and anticipating water-related management challenges, both at the basin scale and at the federal level. This project involved the education and training of students in hands-on research experiences, helping to develop the next generation of scientists.
